channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Two Israeli Jews Stabbed, One Fatally, by Two Palestinians in Jerusalem
item.description: The two assailants died after being shot by the police, and a third Israeli civilian died hours later, apparently after he was hit by police fire, the police said.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israeli forensic experts covering the body of a Palestinian man who was shot dead after a reported stabbing in Jerusalem on Wednesday.

item.title: Israeli Veterans’ Criticism of West Bank Occupation Incites Furor
item.description: A group called Breaking the Silence is at the center of a debate that is exposing Israel’s divisions over its values and the nature of its democracy.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Employees at the offices of Breaking the Silence in Tel Aviv in December. By publishing the testimonies of soldiers, mostly anonymously, the organization highlights what it views as the corrosive nature of the occupation of the West Bank on Israeli society.

item.title: China Landslide: Man Pulled Alive From Shenzhen Debris After 67 Hours
item.description: A young migrant worker rescued Wednesday is the only person saved from a collapsed factory in Shenzhen, China.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS
item.media:description: A survivor is carried out on a stretcher after spending more than 60 hours trapped following a landslide that engulfed dozens of buildings in Shenzhen, China.

item.title: Open Source: Father of Drowned Syrian Boy to Deliver Christmas Message to Britons
item.description: Britain’s Channel 4 will broadcast a recorded message from Abdullah Kurdi, the Syrian refugee whose young son drowned off Turkey in September, on Christmas Day.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Abdullah Kurdi, a Syrian refugee whose son drowned off Turkey this year, recorded a holiday message for Britain's Channel 4.

item.title: Frenchman Held in Jihadist Killing Commits Suicide
item.description: Yassin Salhi, who was charged with beheading his boss and attacking an American-owned chemical plant in France, hanged himself in his prison cell, officials said.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: A man believed to be Yassin Salhi was arrested in Saint-Priest, near Lyon, France, in June.

item.title: Barring of British Muslim Family Flying to Disneyland Touches Nerve
item.description: The passengers said American officers at Gatwick Airport near London did not give a reason for denying them permission to board a flight to Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Istanbul Journal: Syrian Migrants in Istanbul Confront Choice: Stay or Move On
item.description: A question has come to dominate the lives of thousands of Syrians here: Embark on a perilous journey to Europe or build a new life in Turkey.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Samer Alkadri, a painter and graphic designer from Damascus, opened a bookstore and cafe in Istanbul in July. Roughly 350,000 Syrians live in the city.

item.title: Migrant Workers in Shenzhen Bear Brunt of Landslide
item.description: They make up more than 80 percent of the city’s population, and they represent many of those missing or displaced by the massive landslide.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A survivor was rescued early Wednesday from the site of a landslide in Shenzhen, China.

item.title: Sinosphere: Stephon Marbury Gains Museum, and Green Card, in China
item.description: He has already been honored with a statue, a musical based on his life and a series of postage stamps.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: The basketball star Stephon Marbury celebrating in Shenyang, China, in March after leading the Beijing Ducks to their third Chinese Basketball Association championship in four years.

item.title: Iraq Sends More Troops to Fight ISIS in Ramadi
item.description: Soldiers pushed toward a government complex and battled to regain control of a southern district in the second day of an offensive to retake the city.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Iraqi forces south of Ramadi, Iraq, on Tuesday. Iraqi military officials have said the offensive to retake the central city will take days, with soldiers facing stiff resistance from Islamic State militants and an urban landscape laden with hidden explosives.

item.title: 13 Migrants Drown Off Turkish Coast
item.description: The boat, nearly 20 feet long, was carrying 29 migrants, when it capsized Tuesday night, a spokeswoman said.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Bulgarian Border Police Accused of Abusing Refugees
item.description: Interviews with aid workers and dozens of refugees revealed a widespread fear of the authorities. But it is not known how common abuse is.
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers expanding a border fence on the outskirts of the small Bulgarian village of Lesovo this month. Refugees have reported being beaten and robbed by Bulgarian border guards while crossing from Turkey.

item.title: French Police Make 2,700 Raids in Month, Raising Tension With Muslims
item.description: The use of such tactics under a nationwide state of emergency has Muslim leaders saying that their communities are being unfairly targeted.
item.dc:creator: DEBORAH ACOSTA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How Saddam Hussein Gave Us ISIS
item.description: The Islamic State was born when the desperate dictator turned to religion to shore up his teetering regime.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KYLE W. ORTON

item.title: Sinosphere: A Peek Into the Mind of China’s Internet Users
item.description: People this year wanted to find out about health, money, the law and love — or marriage, at least.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY and PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Family, Football and Quiet Pride Defined Service Members Killed in Afghanistan
item.description: The six Americans who were killed on Monday by a suicide bomber were part of an Air Force team trained in counterterrorism. Family and friends recalled their varied passions in interviews and online.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: DAVE PHILIPPS and ASHLEY SOUTHALL

item.title: Iraqi Forces Fighting ISIS for Ramadi Push Toward City Center
item.description: Soldiers began a fierce assault against the Islamic State, and by Tuesday evening had reached the edges of the city center despite heavy resistance.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY, SEWELL CHAN and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers in northern Ramadi, Iraq, on Monday.

item.title: Turkey Moves to Clamp Down on Border, Long a Revolving Door
item.description: Under growing pressure from Europe and the United States, the country has worked to cut off flows of refugees and foreign fighters.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: A Turkish Coast Guard searchlight exposed a boat carrying Syrian migrants. Turkey has been tightening its borders.

item.title: Botched Vote in Argentina Reflects Trouble in South America
item.description: Seventy-five voters somehow produced a 38-38 tie, offering a view into the perils new figures face in trying to control the region’s soccer organizations in the wake of a sweeping corruption scandal.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: Luis Segura this month at the election for the Argentine soccer federation presidency. He tied Marcelo Tinelli in the vote, 38-38 — even though there were only 75 voters.

item.title: In the Dirtiest Cities, Air Pollution Forces Life Changes
item.description: Residents of some of the world’s most heavily polluted cities shared their experiences dealing with the daily challenges and consequences.
item.dc:creator: SONA PATEL
item.media:description: Smog on the outskirts in New Delhi last year. Life in the world's most polluted cities presents an array of challenges and perils for residents.
